H0.text: In business theory which one of these is not normally a 'profit lever'. Revenue

H1.text: In business theory which one of these is not normally a 'profit lever'. Cost

H2.text: In business theory which one of these is not normally a 'profit lever'. Market Share

H3.text: In business theory which one of these is not normally a 'profit lever'. Time

A4.text: Profit is the difference between total revenue and total cost.

A5.text: The goal of maximizing profit is also what leads firms to enter markets where economic profit exists, with the main focus being to maximize production without significantly increasing its marginal cost per good.

A6.text: The contribution margin is the revenue excess from sales over variable costs.

A7.text: Over time, these 'fixed costs' have become more important to managers.

A8.text: Consistent revenue growth, if accompanied by net income growth, contributes to the value of an enterprise and therefore the share price.

A9.text: If a company displays solid 'top-line growth', analysts could view the period's performance as positive even if earnings growth, or 'bottom-line growth' is stagnant.

A10.text: Self-service...lower costs for the firm and perhaps prices

A11.text: the 1970s paradigm was the pursuit of market share (size and scale) influenced by the experience curve

A12.text: Effective time management is essential for maximizing Return on Time Invested (ROTI).

A13.text: Time management is the process of planning and exercising conscious control of time spent on specific activitiesâ€”especially to increase effectiveness, efficiency and productivity.
